title: High Blood Pressure and Chronic Diseases
content: High blood pressure contributes to many chronic diseases, playing a significant role in all the major chronic diseases, except for cancer. It is extraordinarily common, with maybe 1/3 of adults having high blood pressure. High blood pressure is usually defined as a blood pressure greater than 140 over 90, but in the US it was recently redefined as being greater than 130/80. There are 3 main sites where high blood pressure really causes problems: stroke, heart failure, and kidney disease. These are all pressure related conditions where the higher the pressure the higher the risk of these diseases.

title: Blood Pressure and Disease Risk
content: Studies show that the greatest risk for these diseases occurs when the systolic blood pressure is 160-180 or higher. There is a linear relationship between blood pressure and the risk of stroke and heart failure going all the way down to 120/80. Most studies done in around 1900 showed that less than 5% of the population had blood pressures of over 140 over 90. Based upon the normal Gaussian curve of the population back then, probably about 140 over 90 was the cutoff for what was thought to be high blood pressure.

title: Blood Pressure Management
content: 140 over 90 is a good mark for where we should be viewing hypertension as a condition that really should involve active management. There is minimal risk with a blood pressure 135 over 85. In epidemiology studies over many years, it can be shown that 120/80 is superior to 135/ 85.

title: Professional Experience
content: A professor of medicine in the Department of Nephrology at the University of Colorado since 2008 and has spent the last 19 years being a division chief across three very prestigious medical schools. Has well over 700 publications in JAMA, New England Journal of Medicine, Science, et cetera. Has lectured across 40 countries, authored two books, including The Fat Switch, and has been funded extensively by the National Institute of Health (NIH).

title: Research Focus
content: Primary focus in research has been on the mechanisms causing kidney disease. Became really interested in the connection between fructose (and fructose metabolism) and obesity, diabetes, heart disease, hypertension, and metabolic disease.
